abstract.t: This document defines a new Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) object type called RPKI AS-SET Authorization (RASA). RASA allows autonomous systems to cryptographically sign the membership of their AS-SETs, enabling secure AS-SET verification during route filter generation.

The RASA object addresses a fundamental limitation of existing IRR-based AS-SET mechanisms: the inability to verify AS-SET membership cryptographically. By storing AS-SET membership in RPKI-signed objects, operators can generate route filters with cryptographic assurance that AS-SET members are authentic.

section.name: Introduction
section.t: Internet Routing Registry (IRR) databases have long been used to generate BGP route filters. The Routing Policy Specification Language (RPSL) defines the as-set object, which represents a set of autonomous systems. However, IRR-based AS-SETs suffer from a fundamental security limitation: membership is controlled solely by the AS-SET owner, without cryptographic verification or member authorization.
This creates two significant problems:

ol.li: Unauthorized Inclusion: An AS-SET owner can include any autonomous system without authorization, potentially allowing route leaks or policy violations.

Transitive Chain Attacks: AS-SET expansion is transitive - if AS-SET A contains AS-SET B, and B contains AS C, then A implicitly contains C. This creates a chain of trust where compromising any link compromises the entire chain.

section.t: RPKI AS-SET Authorization (RASA) addresses these limitations by:

ul.li: Providing cryptographic signatures for AS-SET membership via RPKI
Enabling verification during AS-SET expansion
Supporting "do-not-inherit" semantics to prevent transitive attacks
Maintaining backward compatibility with existing IRR infrastructure

section.name: Terminology
section.t: The key words MUST, MUST NOT, REQUIRED, SHALL, SHALL NOT, SHOULD, SHOULD NOT, RECOMMENDED, MAY, and OPTIONAL in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 .

dl.dd: Containing Autonomous System - the AS that owns the AS-SET
Member Autonomous System - an AS listed as a member
An RPSL name identifying an AS-SET (e.g., AS6939:AS-HURRICANE, AS1299:AS-TWELVE99)

section.name: Design Rationale
section.t: The RASA design is informed by several existing mechanisms and their limitations:

section.name: IRR-Based Approaches
section.t: IRR-based AS-SETs rely on the AS-SET owner's mnt-by attribute for authentication. This has several weaknesses:

ul.li: No cryptographic verification of membership
Members cannot prevent unauthorized inclusion
Transitive inclusion cannot be controlled
Authentication relies on passwords or PGP keys in IRR

section.t: The member-of-as-set proposal addresses some of these issues but requires the IRR database to support a new object type and does not provide cryptographic verification.

Prior work by Snijders and Korsbäck proposed ASGroup , an RPKI-based AS grouping mechanism with a complex opt-out mechanism. RASA takes a different approach with a simplified model that prioritizes IRR compatibility and incremental deployment. The opt-out mechanism in ASGroup proved difficult to reason about operationally and added significant complexity to both specification and implementation.

section.name: ASPA Comparison
section.t: Autonomous System Provider Authorization (ASPA) provides cryptographic verification of provider relationships. ASPA proves that a Customer AS (CAS) has authorized a Provider AS (PAS) as its upstream.
However, ASPA has a different scope than RASA:

ul.li: ASPA proves provider-customer relationships
RASA proves AS-SET membership
ASPA is used during BGP path validation
RASA is used during route filter generation

section.t: While both use RPKI, they serve complementary purposes and are not interchangeable.

section.name: Design Goals
section.t: RASA is designed with the following goals:

ol.li: Cryptographic Verification: Use RPKI signing to ensure AS-SET membership cannot be spoofed
Member Protection: Prevent unauthorized inclusion of ASNs in AS-SETs
Chain Control: Allow AS-SET owners to prevent transitive inclusion attacks
Backward Compatibility: Work alongside existing IRR infrastructure
Incremental Deployment: Provide value even with partial adoption

section.name: RASA Objects
section.t: RASA defines two separate RPKI object types that work together to provide complete AS-SET authorization:

ol.li: RASA-SET: Defines AS-SET membership (published by AS-SET owner). Replaces the IRR as-set object.
RASA-AUTH: Defines which AS-SETs may include an ASN or AS-SET (published by ASN or AS-SET owner). Replaces the IRR member-of-as-set functionality.

section.t: These objects are intentionally separate to maintain clear separation of concerns and allow independent deployment. The two-object design is discussed further in Section 4.3.

section.name: RASA-SET Object
section.t: The RASA-SET object defines the membership of an AS-SET. It is published by the AS that owns the AS-SET (the containingAS).

section.name: Object Format
section.t: The RASA-SET object is encoded using CMS with the SignedData content type. The eContentType is:
section.sourcecode: id-rpki-rasa-set OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-rpki 42 1 }
section.t: The RASA-SET content has the following ASN.1 structure:
Note: ASID is defined as INTEGER (0..4294967295) per RFC 3779. The OID arc id-rpki will be assigned by IANA during the publication process.
section.sourcecode: RasaSetContent ::= SEQUENCE { version [0] INTEGER DEFAULT 0, asSetName UTF8String, containingAS ASID, members SEQUENCE OF ASID, nestedSets SEQUENCE OF UTF8String OPTIONAL, irrSource UTF8String OPTIONAL, flags RasaFlags OPTIONAL, notBefore GeneralizedTime, notAfter GeneralizedTime }

dl.dd: The version of the RASA-SET format. This document defines version 0.
The name of the AS-SET (e.g., "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99"). MUST start with "AS-" per RFC2622.
The ASN of the AS that owns this AS-SET. Must match the AS in hierarchical names (e.g., 1299 for AS1299:AS-TWELVE99).
List of ASNs that are members of this AS-SET. Each ASID must be unique and sorted. The containingAS MAY be included.

OPTIONAL list of other AS-SET names that are members of this AS-SET. Enables recursive AS-SET expansion. Each nested set will be resolved by looking up its RASA-SET (or falling back to IRR if no RASA-SET exists).
OPTIONAL authoritative IRR database for this AS-SET (e.g., "RADB", "RIPE"). Prevents namespace ambiguity.
Optional flags: doNotInherit (prevent transitive inclusion), authoritative (RASA-SET replaces IRR data).

section.name: RASA-AUTH Object
section.t: The RASA-AUTH object contains an authorization statement from an autonomous system or AS-SET owner, granting permission for inclusion in specified parent AS-SETs. It is published by the ASN or AS-SET owner to control inclusion authorization.

section.name: Object Format
section.t: The RASA-AUTH object is encoded using CMS with the SignedData content type. The eContentType is:
section.sourcecode: id-rpki-rasa-auth OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-rpki 42 2 }
section.t: The RASA-AUTH content has the following ASN.1 structure:

dl.dd: The version of the RASA-AUTH format. This document defines version 0. Future versions may add new features.

ul.li: authorizedAS: The ASN that is authorizing inclusion. Use for individual ASNs.
authorizedSet: The AS-SET name that is authorizing inclusion. Use for AS-SETs that may be included in other AS-SETs.

dl.dd: Each entry is an AuthorizedEntry containing asSetName (the AS-SET name) and optionally propagation (PropagationScope). If propagation is absent, it defaults to unrestricted. The propagation field signals BGP import policy preferences: unrestricted (default) has no special semantics; directOnly advises the containing AS to only accept routes with this ASN from direct BGP sessions (peer lock signal). An empty list means the ASN refuses inclusion in any AS-SET.
Optional flags controlling authorization behavior. strictMode: If set, AS-SETs NOT in this list MUST NOT include this ASN (reject rather than warn).

section.name: Design Overview
section.t: RASA defines two separate RPKI object types:

dl.dd: Published by the AS-SET owner (e.g., AS1299). Contains the AS-SET membership list (ASNs and nested AS-SETs).
Published by the ASN or AS-SET owner. Authorizes inclusion of the ASN (via authorizedAS) or AS-SET (via authorizedSet) in specific parent AS-SETs.

section.t: This separation maintains cryptographic boundaries: only the ASN owner can authorize inclusion, preventing AS-SET owners from claiming unauthorized membership.

section.name: RASA Verification
section.t: RASA objects are verified using standard RPKI validation procedures.

section.name: Signature Validation
section.t: The RASA object MUST be validated according to :

ol.li: Verify the CMS signature and certificate chain per .
Verify the certificate's subject matches the containingAS (for RASA-SET) or authorizedAS/authorizedSet (for RASA-AUTH).

section.name: Content Validation
section.t: In addition to signature validation, the RASA content MUST be validated for conformance to this specification:

ol.li: The asSetName MUST start with "AS-" (case-insensitive). RASA objects with asSetName not conforming to RFC2622 naming conventions MUST be rejected. This prevents namespace collisions between AS-SETs and autonomous system numbers.
For hierarchical AS-SET names (e.g., "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99"), the ASN component MUST match the containingAS field.
The members list MUST contain only valid ASNs (no AS-SET names in the members list; nested AS-SETs are handled via expansion).
All ASIDs in the members list MUST be sorted in ascending order with no duplicates.

section.name: AS-SET Expansion with RASA
section.t: When expanding an AS-SET for route filter generation, RPKI-aware tools SHOULD perform the following algorithm:

ol.li: Query RPKI for a RASA object for the AS-SET. If a valid RASA exists and the authoritative flag is set, use ONLY the RASA member list. Do NOT query IRR for this AS-SET. The IRR object is treated as deprecated/non-authoritative.

If a valid RASA exists but authoritative is NOT set, determine the IRR database(s) to query: if irrSource is specified, query ONLY that database. If irrSource is absent, query all configured IRR databases. Merge the RASA member list with the IRR member list.
If no valid RASA exists, query IRR using the same database selection logic (irrSource if present, otherwise all databases).

For each nested AS-SET in the member list, first verify if the nested AS-SET has published a RASA-AUTH (with authorizedSet). If so, verify the current AS-SET name is in the authorizedIn list. If not authorized, skip the nested AS-SET and log a warning. If authorized (or no RASA-AUTH exists), recurse using the same algorithm. If the parent AS-SET has doNotInherit set, include only the AS-SET reference (not its members) in the expansion. Note: The propagation field in RASA-AUTH is for BGP import policy signaling and does NOT affect AS-SET expansion.

For each member ASN, verify if a RASA object exists that lists this AS-SET as authorized. If the ASN has published a RASA and this AS-SET is not in the authorized list, exclude the ASN. The strictMode flag controls logging: if TRUE, log a security event; if FALSE, log a warning.

section.t: The irrSource field prevents namespace ambiguity attacks where the same AS-SET name exists in multiple IRR databases with different members. When specified, tools MUST NOT query other IRR databases.

section.name: Conflict Resolution
section.t: When both RASA-SET and RASA-AUTH objects exist for the same AS-SET membership claim, validators MUST apply the following resolution rules to determine the authoritative membership list.

section.name: Priority Rules
section.t: RASA-AUTH (member's intent) takes precedence over RASA-SET (owner's claim). The rationale is that an AS should have control over which AS-SETs include it, as inclusion affects their routing security.

ol.li: For each member ASN claimed in RASA-SET.members, check if a RASA-AUTH object exists signed by that ASN.

If RASA-AUTH exists: verify this AS-SET name is in the RASA-AUTH.authorizedIn list. If present, include the ASN. If the AS-SET is not in authorizedIn, exclude the ASN. Note: The propagation field (directOnly/unrestricted) does NOT affect AS-SET expansion decisions. It is an advisory signal for BGP import policy at the containing AS's discretion.
If RASA-AUTH exists and strictMode is set to TRUE, exclude the ASN and log a security event (unauthorized inclusion).
If RASA-AUTH exists and strictMode is FALSE, exclude the ASN but log a warning (member may not want inclusion).
If no RASA-AUTH exists, include the ASN if the AS-SET owner's RASA-SET is valid.

section.name: Conflict Examples
section.t: Example 1: Member authorizes inclusion
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS2914 publishes): asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" members: [AS64496, AS64497, AS15169]
RASA-AUTH (AS15169 publishes): authorizedEntity: authorizedAS: 15169 authorizedIn: - asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" propagation: unrestricted - asSetName: "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99" propagation: unrestricted strictMode: FALSE
Result: AS15169 is INCLUDED (authorized)
section.t: Example 2: Member does not authorize inclusion
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS-EVIL publishes): asSetName: "AS-EVIL:CUSTOMERS" members: [AS64496, AS15169]
RASA-AUTH (AS15169 publishes): authorizedEntity: authorizedAS: 15169 authorizedIn: - asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" propagation: unrestricted strictMode: TRUE
Result: AS15169 is EXCLUDED (not authorized), security event logged
section.t: Example 3: No RASA-AUTH from member
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS2914 publishes): asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" members: [AS64496, AS64497, AS398465]
RASA-AUTH (AS398465): None published
Result: AS398465 is INCLUDED (no objection from member)
section.t: Example 4: AS-SET authorization
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS2914 publishes): asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" nestedSets: ["AS1299:AS-TWELVE99"]
RASA-AUTH (AS1299 publishes): authorizedEntity: authorizedSet: "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99" authorizedIn: - asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" propagation: unrestricted strictMode: TRUE
Result: AS1299:AS-TWELVE99 is INCLUDED (authorized)
section.t: Example 5: AS-SET authorization denied
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS-EVIL publishes): asSetName: "AS-EVIL:CUSTOMERS" nestedSets: ["AS1299:AS-TWELVE99"]
RASA-AUTH (AS1299 publishes): authorizedEntity: authorizedSet: "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99" authorizedIn: - asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" propagation: unrestricted strictMode: TRUE
Result: AS1299:AS-TWELVE99 is EXCLUDED (not authorized in AS-EVIL)
section.t: Example 6: Peer Lock Signal (BGP Import Policy)
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS2914 publishes): asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" members: [AS15169, AS64496]
RASA-AUTH (AS15169 publishes): authorizedEntity: authorizedAS: 15169 authorizedIn: - asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" propagation: directOnly -- BGP import policy signal strictMode: TRUE
AS-SET Expansion (for prefix-list generation): Result: AS15169 is INCLUDED normally in AS2914:AS-GLOBAL Note: propagation field does NOT affect AS-SET membership
BGP Import Policy (how NTT may use the signal): NTT MAY apply the following to routes with AS15169 in path: - ACCEPT from direct BGP sessions with AS15169 - REJECT from route servers, transit, or other indirect paths
This is an advisory signal. Implementation is at NTT's discretion. The signal helps NTT prevent route leaks and ensure clean paths.

section.name: Circular Reference Detection
section.t: RASA-SET objects support nested AS-SET references via the nestedSets field. This creates the potential for circular references if an AS-SET includes itself, directly or indirectly.
Validators MUST detect and handle circular references to prevent infinite loops during AS-SET expansion.

section.name: Detection Algorithm
section.t: During AS-SET expansion, validators MUST maintain a "seen" set containing all AS-SET names encountered in the current expansion chain.

ol.li: Initialize an empty set 'seen' before expanding an AS-SET.
Before expanding any AS-SET (via RASA-SET or IRR), check if its name is already in 'seen'.
If yes: circular reference detected. Stop expanding this branch and log a warning. Do not include any members from the circular AS-SET.
If no: add the AS-SET name to 'seen' and continue expansion.
When backtracking from a nested AS-SET, remove its name from 'seen' to allow valid reuse in different branches.

section.name: Circular Reference Example
section.sourcecode:
RASA-SET (AS2914): asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" members: [AS64496] nestedSets: ["AS64496:AS-SET"]
RASA-SET (AS64496): asSetName: "AS64496:AS-SET" members: [AS398465] nestedSets: ["AS2914:AS-GLOBAL"] -- circular!
Expansion trace: 1. Start: AS2914:AS-GLOBAL (seen={}) 2. Add AS2914:AS-GLOBAL to seen 3. Expand AS64496:AS-SET (seen={AS2914:AS-GLOBAL}) 4. Add AS64496:AS-SET to seen 5. Attempt to expand AS2914:AS-GLOBAL 6. Detect: AS2914:AS-GLOBAL already in seen 7. Log warning, stop expansion, return [AS64496] only

section.name: Content Provider Protection
section.t: Google (AS15169) wants to ensure it is only included in specific Tier-1 provider AS-SETs:
section.sourcecode: RASA Object (signed by AS15169): asSetName: "AS15169:AS-GOOGLE" containingAS: 15169 members: [15169, 16509, 36040, 36384] flags: doNotInherit(0) = TRUE
section.t: Now when a malicious AS-SET includes AS15169:AS-GOOGLE, expansion stops at the AS-SET reference and does not include Google's actual ASNs, preventing route leaks.

section.name: Tier-1 Provider Protection
section.t: Arelion (AS1299) wants to protect its customer AS-SET:
section.sourcecode: RASA Object (signed by AS1299): asSetName: "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99" containingAS: 1299 members: [64496, 64497, 64498, 64499, ...] flags: doNotInherit(0) = TRUE, authoritative(1) = TRUE
section.t: The authoritative flag tells tools to use this RASA member list instead of the IRR data. The doNotInherit flag prevents transitive inclusion attacks.

section.name: Enterprise Multi-ASN
section.t: An enterprise with multiple ASNs wants consistent authorization:
section.sourcecode: RASA Object (signed by enterprise AS): asSetName: "AS64501:AS-ENTERPRISE" containingAS: 64501 members: [64501, 64502, 64503] flags: authoritative(1) = TRUE

section.name: IRR Namespace Binding
section.t: Hurricane Electric (AS6939) wants to prevent namespace ambiguity attacks where AS6939:AS-HURRICANE exists in multiple IRR databases:
section.sourcecode: RASA Object (signed by AS6939): asSetName: "AS6939:AS-HURRICANE" containingAS: 6939 irrSource: "RADB" members: [6939, 1, 2, 3, ...] flags: authoritative(1) = TRUE, doNotInherit(0) = TRUE
section.t: The irrSource field locks AS6939:AS-HURRICANE to the RADB database only. Tools will NOT query RIPE, ARIN, or other databases for this AS-SET. This prevents attackers from registering AS6939:AS-HURRICANE in other databases with malicious members.

section.name: Security Considerations
section.t: RASA provides cryptographic assurance of AS-SET membership, but several security considerations apply:

section.name: Partial Deployment
section.t: During partial deployment, some AS-SETs will not have RASA objects. Tools SHOULD:

ul.li: Default to IRR data when RASA is unavailable (backward compatibility)
Provide configuration options to require RASA for specific AS-SETs or all AS-SETs
Log warnings when falling back to IRR for high-value AS-SETs

section.name: Chain Attack Mitigation
section.t: The doNotInherit flag mitigates transitive chain attacks. However, if an AS-SET owner does not set this flag, their members remain vulnerable to transitive inclusion. AS-SET owners should carefully consider whether their AS-SET should be transitively inheritable.

section.name: Chain-of-Trust Limitations
section.t: RASA provides cryptographic verification of individual AS-SETs, but a fundamental limitation remains: AS-SET expansion is transitive. When AS-SET A contains AS-SET B, and B contains AS-SET C, then A implicitly contains all members of C.

This creates a chain-of-trust problem: an attacker who compromises any AS-SET in the expansion chain can include arbitrary ASNs. For example, if a malicious actor creates AS-EVIL containing AS15169:AS-GOOGLE, and AS15169:AS-GOOGLE has not set the doNotInherit flag, then AS-EVIL inherits all Google ASNs.

Critical Requirement: For full security, every AS-SET in the expansion chain must protect itself. If any AS-SET in the chain lacks RASA protection or does not set doNotInherit, the entire chain remains vulnerable to transitive attacks.

This limitation is not unique to RASA - it affects all AS-SET-based routing, including IRR-based AS-SETs. The difference is that RASA provides a mechanism (doNotInherit) for AS-SET owners to break the chain. Full protection requires widespread adoption at the internet core: Tier-1 providers and major content networks must publish RASA objects with appropriate flags.

section.name: Deployment Considerations
section.t: RASA is designed for incremental deployment. Content providers and Tier-1 operators can publish RASA objects immediately, even before widespread tool support.

An alternative approach uses existing ASPA objects to synthesize AS-SET membership from provider relationships. While this requires no new object types, it only captures provider-customer relationships and lacks authorization semantics.

section.name: ASPA-RASA Relationship
section.t: ASPA synthesis and RASA serve complementary purposes:

ul.li: ASPA-derived AS-SETs represent provider-customer relationships discovered from ASPA objects. These are dynamic - membership changes as ASPAs are published or withdrawn.
RASA objects represent explicit AS-SET membership declarations with authorization controls.

section.t: Operators may use ASPA-derived AS-SETs for provider-customer relationships while using RASA for complex multi-lateral groupings requiring authorization.

section.name: Operational Guidance
section.t: This section provides practical guidance for network operators deploying RASA in production environments.

section.name: Publishing RASA Objects
section.t: To publish a RASA object, an AS operator must:

ol.li: Generate a RPKI certificate for their AS if not already available through their Regional Internet Registry (RIR).
Create the RASA content specifying the AS-SET name, containing AS, member list, and appropriate flags.
Sign the RASA object using their RPKI private key via CMS .
Publish the signed RASA object to their RPKI repository, typically via their RIR's publication service or a private repository if using delegated RPKI.
Ensure the RASA object is included in the repository manifest and available via rsync or RRDP.

section.name: Consuming RASA Objects
section.t: Operators generating route filters SHOULD integrate RASA validation into their existing IRR tools:

ol.li: Query RPKI repositories for RASA objects alongside IRR AS-SET queries.
Validate RASA signatures using standard RPKI validation libraries (e.g., rpki-client, Routinator).
Apply RASA flags during AS-SET expansion. Honor doNotInherit to prevent transitive inclusion. Prefer authoritative RASA member lists over IRR data. Fall back to IRR data when RASA is unavailable.
Log validation failures and policy decisions for auditing.

section.name: Monitoring and Alerting
section.t: Operators SHOULD monitor RASA validation status:

ul.li: Track RASA objects for critical AS-SETs (content providers, Tier-1 providers) and alert on validation failures.
Monitor RASA object expiration dates and alert before expiry.
Log fallback events when reverting to IRR data due to missing or invalid RASA objects.
Track unexpected AS-SET membership changes detected during RASA validation.

section.name: Example 1: Tier-1 Provider Customer AS-SET
section.t: NTT (AS2914) maintains AS2914:AS-GLOBAL containing their customer ASNs. Here's the complete operational workflow:
section.sourcecode:
Step 1: NTT publishes RASA-SET asSetName: "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" containingAS: 2914 members: [AS64496, AS64497, AS64498, AS64499, AS64500] nestedSets: ["AS64496:AS-SET", "AS64497:AS-SET"] flags: authoritative=TRUE, doNotInherit=FALSE irrSource: "RADB" validity: 2024-01-01 to 2025-01-01
Step 2: Customer AS64496 publishes RASA-AUTH authorizedAS: 64496 authorizedIn: ["AS2914:AS-GLOBAL", "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99"] strictMode: FALSE validity: 2024-01-01 to 2025-01-01
Step 3: Customer AS64497 publishes RASA-AUTH authorizedAS: 64497 authorizedIn: ["AS2914:AS-GLOBAL"] strictMode: TRUE validity: 2024-01-01 to 2025-01-01
Step 4: Customer AS64498 does NOT publish RASA-AUTH (No objection, included by default)
Step 5: Attacker AS-EVIL attempts unauthorized inclusion RASA-SET (AS-EVIL): asSetName: "AS-EVIL:CUSTOMERS" members: [AS64496, AS64497, AS2914] -- attempting to include NTT!
Result: AS2914 excluded (AS-EVIL not in AS2914's authorizedIn list)

section.name: Example 2: Content Provider Multi-AS Protection
section.t: Google operates multiple ASNs and wants to control which Tier-1 providers can include them:
section.sourcecode:
Google publishes RASA-SET for their aggregated AS-SET: asSetName: "AS15169:AS-GOOGLE" containingAS: 15169 members: [15169, 16509, 36040, 36384, 139190] flags: authoritative=TRUE, doNotInherit=TRUE
Google publishes RASA-AUTH for each ASN: authorizedAS: 15169 authorizedIn: ["AS2914:AS-GLOBAL", "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99", "AS6453:AS-TATA", "AS3356:AS-LEVEL3"] strictMode: TRUE
authorizedAS: 16509 (AWS) authorizedIn: ["AS2914:AS-GLOBAL", "AS1299:AS-TWELVE99"] strictMode: TRUE
Result: Google's AS-SET can only be expanded by authorized Tier-1s. Any attempt by malicious AS-SETs to include AS15169:AS-GOOGLE will stop at the AS-SET reference (doNotInherit=TRUE) without revealing the actual Google ASNs.

section.name: Example 3: Complete Validator Decision Flow
section.t: A router configuration generator encounters AS2914:AS-GLOBAL:
section.sourcecode:
Validator processing AS2914:AS-GLOBAL:
1. Query RPKI for RASA-SET "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" Found: Valid RASA-SET from AS2914 authoritative=TRUE, members=[64496, 64497, 64498]
2. For each member, check RASA-AUTH:
Member AS64496: - Query RPKI for RASA-AUTH from AS64496 - Found: authorizedIn contains "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" - Decision: INCLUDE (explicitly authorized)
Member AS64497: - Query RPKI for RASA-AUTH from AS64497 - Found: authorizedIn does NOT contain "AS2914:AS-GLOBAL" - strictMode=FALSE - Decision: EXCLUDE (log warning)
Member AS64498: - Query RPKI for RASA-AUTH from AS64498 - Not found - Decision: INCLUDE (no objection)
3. Process nestedSets (if doNotInherit=FALSE): - For each nested AS-SET, repeat steps 1-2 recursively - Track seen sets to detect circular references
4. Final member list: [AS64496, AS64498]

section.name: Example 6: Partial Deployment Scenario
section.t: During transition, some AS-SETs have RASA and others don't:
section.sourcecode:
Operator wants to expand AS-HURRICANE (AS6939):
Scenario A: AS6939 has published RASA-SET - Query RPKI: Found valid RASA-SET - authoritative=TRUE - Action: Use RASA member list, ignore IRR - IRR AS-HURRICANE treated as deprecated
Scenario B: AS6939 has NOT published RASA-SET - Query RPKI: No RASA found - Action: Query IRR for AS-HURRICANE - Log: "Falling back to IRR for AS-HURRICANE" - Continue with IRR expansion
Scenario C: Some members have RASA-AUTH, others don't - AS6939:AS-HURRICANE contains [AS2914, AS64496, AS-UNKNOWN] - AS2914: No RASA-AUTH found → included - AS64496: Has RASA-AUTH, authorizes AS6939 → included - AS-UNKNOWN: Nested AS-SET, no RASA → expanded from IRR
Result: Mixed RASA/IRR expansion during transition period.

section.name: Relationship to ASGroup
section.t: RASA builds upon the foundational work of Snijders and Korsbäck, who proposed the ASGroup mechanism in 2022. While ASGroup introduced important concepts for RPKI-based AS-SET authorization, it expired without achieving deployment. RASA represents an evolution of these ideas with practical deployment considerations.

section.name: ASGroup Innovations
section.t: ASGroup introduced several important concepts that influenced RASA:

ul.li: RPKI-signed AS group objects providing cryptographic verification of membership.
Separation between the containing AS (group owner) and member ASes.
The concept of controlling transitive inclusion through the referenceable flag.
Recognition that IRR-based AS-SETs lack cryptographic verification.

section.name: RASA Simplifications
section.t: RASA addresses several factors that contributed to ASGroup's complexity:

ul.li: Removed opt-out mechanism: ASGroup's separate Opt-Out Listing objects added significant complexity to validation and reasoning. RASA eliminates opt-out in favor of explicit membership authorization via the member list.
Simplified flag semantics: ASGroup's referenceable boolean was replaced with doNotInherit, providing more intuitive control over transitive inclusion.
IRR compatibility: RASA is designed to work alongside existing IRR infrastructure during transition, whereas ASGroup appeared to be a complete replacement.
Clear deployment path: RASA includes phased deployment guidance with incremental adoption stages.

section.name: Acknowledgments
section.t: The authors acknowledge Job Snijders and Fredrik Korsbäck for their pioneering work on ASGroup, which established the foundation for RPKI-based AS-SET authorization and identified the critical need for cryptographic verification in routing policy.

section.name: IRR Operator Considerations
section.t: The introduction of RASA objects raises several open questions regarding the relationship between RPKI-authenticated AS-SET data and existing IRR database entries. This section documents known issues and potential approaches without making definitive recommendations, as operational experience is required to determine best practices.

section.name: IRR Object Deletion vs Retention
section.t: When an AS-SET owner publishes a RASA object with the authoritative flag set, questions arise regarding the fate of the corresponding IRR AS-SET:

ul.li: Deletion: Should the IRR AS-SET be deleted? Issues include: lack of cryptographic deletion in IRR, persistence in mirrors, and potential breakage of legacy tools that do not yet support RPKI.
Retention: Should the IRR AS-SET be kept indefinitely? Issues include: potential confusion when IRR and RASA data diverge, and validators needing clear precedence rules.
Deprecation markers: Can IRR objects be marked as deprecated? Issues include: lack of standardized deprecation attributes in IRR, and varying support across IRR database implementations.

section.t: Further investigation is needed to understand operational impacts and develop migration guidance.

section.name: IRR-RASA Synchronization
section.t: If both IRR and RASA objects exist for the same AS-SET, synchronization questions arise:

ul.li: Source of truth: When RASA authoritative flag is set, validators use RASA. However, IRR databases may serve stale data to legacy clients. Is dual maintenance required during transition?
Automated updates: Should IRR databases automatically generate AS-SET objects from RASA data? This would require significant IRR infrastructure changes and trust in RPKI validation.
Conflict detection: Should validators detect when IRR and RASA data differ significantly? What actions should be taken on detection?

section.t: Operational deployment experience is needed to inform synchronization strategies.

section.name: Transition Period Management
section.t: The expected 5-10 year transition period raises operational questions:

ul.li: Gradual adoption: How should operators manage AS-SETs where some members have RASA objects and others do not?
Tool compatibility: How should networks handle tools that only query IRR during the transition?
Documentation: What documentation should accompany RASA objects to guide IRR operators and users?

section.t: These questions require community feedback and operational experience before standardization.

section.name: Failure Modes
section.t: This section documents expected failure modes and recommended responses during RASA deployment and operation.

section.name: Signature Validation Failures
section.t: When RASA signature validation fails, operators SHOULD:

ul.li: Fall back to IRR data for the affected AS-SET if configured for backward compatibility.
Log the validation failure with specific error details (expired certificate, invalid signature, revocation, etc.).
Alert operations staff if the failure affects critical AS-SETs and strict RASA mode is enabled.
Continue processing other AS-SETs; do not fail the entire route filter generation.

section.name: Repository Availability Failures
section.t: When RPKI repositories are unavailable:

ul.li: Use cached RASA data if available and within validity period.
Fall back to IRR data with appropriate logging if cached data is unavailable or expired.
Retry repository queries with exponential backoff.
Alert on persistent repository failures affecting validation.

section.name: Policy Violation Failures
section.t: When RASA validation detects policy violations (unauthorized AS-SET inclusion):

ul.li: Exclude the violating ASN from the route filter expansion.
Log the violation with details of the unauthorized inclusion.
Alert network operations if the violation involves high-value AS-SETs or appears to be an attack.
Provide configuration option to warn-only vs. reject for gradual policy adoption.

section.name: Chain Protection Failures
section.t: When an AS-SET in the expansion chain lacks protection:

ul.li: Process the chain normally if the unprotected AS-SET has doNotInherit set (intentionally unprotected).
Log a warning when encountering unprotected AS-SETs in otherwise protected chains.
Provide option to require full chain protection for high-security environments.
Document the specific unprotected AS-SETs for follow-up with operators.

section.name: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requests IANA to:
1. Register two RPKI Object Types:
2. Register file extensions and media types:
